title: Technical Accuracy vs. Propaganda Efficacy in Neoclassical Architecture
context: @plassoplo engages in a debate about a neoclassical architectural sketch by @Ethosrevival meant to inspire European cultural revival. The original post featured a pencil drawing of Roman-inspired arches.
pressure: @plassoplo initially critiques a truncated column as visually 'wrong.' @Ethosrevival defends it as standard drafting technique (breaking the shaft to show base and capital without distortion). The collision: technical correctness vs. persuasive impact for mass audiences.
axiom_trigger: Axiom 1 (No Dissimulation) activates when @plassoplo concedes technical validity while refusing to collapse the distinction between expert documentation and propaganda. He preserves the load-bearing nuance: measured drawings can use breaks; mass-appeal imagery must prioritize symbolic power (tall, slender columns evoking strength) over technical notation.
clean_outcome: Clean pivot. @plassoplo acknowledges both truths without softening either: 'That's correct for measured drawings' AND 'but for inspirational purposes, this visual rhetoric sabotages your own message.' He critiques his own ideological 'side' (European revivalists) for a self-own in persuasion—punching inwards without ego defense.
